title: Linear combinations
content:
According to Wikipedia ("Linear combination", 29-Mar-2019, ~ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_combination ) "In mathematics, a linear combination is an expression constructed from a set of terms by multiplying each term by a constant and adding the results (e.g., a linear combination of x and y would be any expression of the form ax + by, where a and b are constants). The concept of linear combinations is central to linear algebra and related fields of mathematics." In linear algebra, these "terms" are "vectors" (elements from vector spaces or left modules), and the constants are elements of the underlying field resp. ring. This corresponds to the definition in [Lang] p. 129: "Let M be a module over a ring A and let S be a subset of M. By a linear combination of elements of S (with coefficients in A) one means a sum ∑x ∈S axx where {ax} is a set of elements of A, ...". In the definition in [Lang] p. 129, it is additionally claimed that "..., almost all of which [elements of A] are equal to 0.". This is not necessarily required in the following definition ~ df-linc , but it is essential if additions and scalar multiplications of linear combinations are considered. Therefore, we define the set of all linear combinations with finite support in ~ df-lco , so that we can show that such sets are submodules of the corresponding modules, see ~ lincolss .
Remark:According to Wikipedia ("Linear span", 28-Apr-2019, ~ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_span ) "In linear algebra, the linear span (also called the linear hull or just span) of a set of vectors in a vector space [or module] is the intersection of all linear subspaces which each contain every vector in that set.", and "Alternately, the span of [a set] S may be defined as the set of all finite linear combinations of elements (vectors) of S". Whereas spans are defined according to the first approach in ~ df-lsp , the set of all linear combinations as defined by ~ df-lco follows the alternative approach. That both definitions are equivalent is shown by ~ lspeqlco .

df-linc
blocks.content: Define the operation constructing a linear combination. Although this definition is taylored for linear combinations of vectors from left modules, it can be used for any structure having a ` Base ` , ` Scalar ` s and a scalar multiplication ` .s ` . (Contributed by AV, 29-Mar-2019.)
blocks.origin:
axiom df-linc(setvar s0, setvar s1, setvar s2, setvar s3) {
  |- wceq(clinc, cmpt(s0, universe, cmpo(s1, s2, co(cfv(cbs, cfv(csca, cv(s0))), cmap, cv(s2)), cpw(cfv(cbs, cv(s0))), co(cv(s0), cgsu, cmpt(s3, cv(s2), co(cfv(cv(s1), cv(s3)), cfv(cvsca, cv(s0)), cv(s3)))))))
  -| diffss(s0, s1)
  -| diffss(s0, s2)
  -| diffss(s0, s3)
  -| diffss(s1, s2)
  -| diffss(s1, s3)
  -| diffss(s2, s3)
}
blocks.pretty:
axiom df-linc(setvar s0, setvar s1, setvar s2, setvar s3) {
  ‚ä¢ linC =(s0 ‚àà ùïå ‚Ü¶(s1 ‚àà((Base `(Scalar ` s0))[‚Ü¶]s2), s2 ‚àà P((Base ` s0))‚Ü¶(s0[gsum](s3 ‚àà s2 ‚Ü¶((s1 ` s3)[(√ó ` s0)]s3)))))
  ‚ä£ d(s0, s1)
  ‚ä£ d(s0, s2)
  ‚ä£ d(s0, s3)
  ‚ä£ d(s1, s2)
  ‚ä£ d(s1, s3)
  ‚ä£ d(s2, s3)
}

blocks.name: df-lco
blocks.content: Define the operation constructing the set of all linear combinations for a set of vectors. (Contributed by AV, 31-Mar-2019.) (Revised by AV, 28-Jul-2019.)
blocks.origin:
axiom df-lco(setvar s0, setvar s1, setvar s2, setvar s3) {
  |- wceq(clinco, cmpo(s0, s1, universe, cpw(cfv(cbs, cv(s0))), crab(s2, cfv(cbs, cv(s0)), wrex(s3, co(cfv(cbs, cfv(csca, cv(s0))), cmap, cv(s1)), wa(wbr(cv(s3), cfsupp, cfv(c0g, cfv(csca, cv(s0)))), wceq(cv(s2), co(cv(s3), cfv(clinc, cv(s0)), cv(s1))))))))
  -| diffss(s0, s2)
  -| diffss(s2, s3)
  -| diffss(s1, s2)
  -| diffss(s0, s3)
  -| diffss(s0, s1)
  -| diffss(s1, s3)
}
blocks.pretty:
axiom df-lco(setvar s0, setvar s1, setvar s2, setvar s3) {
  ‚ä¢ LinCo =(s0 ‚àà ùïå, s1 ‚àà P((Base ` s0))‚Ü¶ { s2 ‚àà(Base ` s0)| ‚àÉ(s3 ‚àà((Base `(Scalar ` s0))[‚Ü¶]s1),(s3[finSupp](0 `(Scalar ` s0))‚àß s2 =(s3[(linC ` s0)]s1)))})
  ‚ä£ d(s0, s2)
  ‚ä£ d(s2, s3)
  ‚ä£ d(s1, s2)
  ‚ä£ d(s0, s3)
  ‚ä£ d(s0, s1)
  ‚ä£ d(s1, s3)
}

  ‚ä¢ (c0 ‚àà c1 ‚Üí(linC ` c0)=(s0 ‚àà((Base `(Scalar ` c0))[‚Ü¶]s1), s1 ‚àà P((Base ` c0))‚Ü¶(c0[gsum](s2 ‚àà s1 ‚Ü¶((s0 ` s2)[(√ó ` c0)]s2)))))
  ‚ä£ d(s0, s1)
  ‚ä£ d(s0, s2)
  ‚ä£ d(s1, s2)
  ‚ä£ d(s0, c0)
  ‚ä£ d(s1, c0)
  ‚ä£ d(s1, c1)
  ‚ä£ d(s2, c0)
} = {
  fvmptd3(hs0, clinc, c0, (s0 ‚àà((Base `(Scalar ` c0))[‚Ü¶]s1), s1 ‚àà P((Base ` c0))‚Ü¶(c0[gsum](s2 ‚àà s1 ‚Ü¶((s0 ` s2)[(√ó ` c0)]s2)))), universe, (s0 ‚àà((Base `(Scalar ` hs0))[‚Ü¶]s1), s1 ‚àà P((Base ` hs0))‚Ü¶(hs0[gsum](s2 ‚àà s1 ‚Ü¶((s0 ` s2)[(√ó ` hs0)]s2)))), universe, c0 ‚àà c1)

  id(hs0 = c0)

  pwex((Base ` c0))

thm lincval(setvar s0, class c0, class c1, class c2, class c3) {
  |- wi(w3a(wcel(c0, c1), wcel(c2, co(cfv(cbs, cfv(csca, c0)), cmap, c3)), wcel(c3, cpw(cfv(cbs, c0)))), wceq(co(c2, cfv(clinc, c0), c3), co(c0, cgsu, cmpt(s0, c3, co(cfv(c2, cv(s0)), cfv(cvsca, c0), cv(s0))))))
  -| diffsc(s0, c0)
  -| diffsc(s0, c2)
  -| diffsc(s0, c3)
} = {
  eqtrd(co(c2, cfv(clinc, c0), c3), co(c0, cgsu, cmpt(s0, c3, co(cfv(c2, cv(s0)), cfv(cvsca, c0), cv(s0)))), co(c2, cmpo(hs0, hs1, co(cfv(cbs, cfv(csca, c0)), cmap, cv(hs1)), cpw(cfv(cbs, c0)), co(c0, cgsu, cmpt(s0, cv(hs1), co(cfv(cv(hs0), cv(s0)), cfv(cvsca, c0), cv(s0))))), c3), w3a(wcel(c0, c1), wcel(c2, co(cfv(cbs, cfv(csca, c0)), cmap, c3)), wcel(c3, cpw(cfv(cbs, c0)))))

  simp2(wcel(c0, c1), wcel(c2, co(cfv(cbs, cfv(csca, c0)), cmap, c3)), wcel(c3, cpw(cfv(cbs, c0))))
  simp3(wcel(c0, c1), wcel(c2, co(cfv(cbs, cfv(csca, c0)), cmap, c3)), wcel(c3, cpw(cfv(cbs, c0))))
  ovexd(c0, cgsu, cmpt(s0, c3, co(cfv(c2, cv(s0)), cfv(cvsca, c0), cv(s0))), w3a(wcel(c0, c1), wcel(c2, co(cfv(cbs, cfv(csca, c0)), cmap, c3)), wcel(c3, cpw(cfv(cbs, c0)))))

  eqcomd(cmpt(hs0, cv(s2), co(cfv(cv(s1), cv(hs0)), cfv(cvsca, cv(s0)), cv(hs0))), co(cv(s1), cof(cfv(cvsca, cv(s0))), cres(cid, cv(s2))), wa(wcel(cv(s1), co(cfv(cbs, cfv(csca, cv(s0))), cmap, cv(s2))), wcel(cv(s2), cpw(cfv(cbs, cv(s0))))))

  -| wceq(c3, cfv(cbs, c0))

} = {

  |- wi(wa(wcel(c0, c1), wcel(c2, cpw(c3))), wb(wcel(c4, co(c0, clinco, c2)), wa(wcel(c4, c3), wrex(s0, co(c5, cmap, c2), wa(wbr(cv(s0), cfsupp, cfv(c0g, c6)), wceq(c4, co(cv(s0), cfv(clinc, c0), c2)))))))
  -| wceq(c3, cfv(cbs, c0))
  -| wceq(c6, cfv(csca, c0))

  -| diffsc(s0, c0)

  -| diffsc(s0, c4)
  -| diffsc(s0, c5)
} = {
  syl6bb(wa(wcel(c0, c1), wcel(c2, cpw(c3))), wcel(c4, co(c0, clinco, c2)), wa(wcel(c4, c3), wrex(s0, co(c5, cmap, c2), wa(wbr(cv(s0), cfsupp, cfv(c0g, c6)), wceq(c4, co(cv(s0), cfv(clinc, c0), c2))))), wcel(c4, crab(hs0, c3, wrex(s0, co(c5, cmap, c2), wa(wbr(cv(s0), cfsupp, cfv(c0g, c6)), wceq(cv(hs0), co(cv(s0), cfv(clinc, c0), c2)))))))
  eleq2d(c4, co(c0, clinco, c2), crab(hs0, c3, wrex(s0, co(c5, cmap, c2), wa(wbr(cv(s0), cfsupp, cfv(c0g, c6)), wceq(cv(hs0), co(cv(s0), cfv(clinc, c0), c2))))), wa(wcel(c0, c1), wcel(c2, cpw(c3))))
  lcoop(hs0, s0, c0, c1, c2, c3, c5, c6)
  elrab(hs0, c4, c3, wrex(s0, co(c5, cmap, c2), wa(wbr(cv(s0), cfsupp, cfv(c0g, c6)), wceq(cv(hs0), co(cv(s0), cfv(clinc, c0), c2)))), wrex(s0, co(c5, cmap, c2), wa(wbr(cv(s0), cfsupp, cfv(c0g, c6)), wceq(c4, co(cv(s0), cfv(clinc, c0), c2)))))
  rexbidv(s0, co(c5, cmap, c2), wceq(cv(hs0), c4), wa(wbr(cv(s0), cfsupp, cfv(c0g, c6)), wceq(cv(hs0), co(cv(s0), cfv(clinc, c0), c2))), wa(wbr(cv(s0), cfsupp, cfv(c0g, c6)), wceq(c4, co(cv(s0), cfv(clinc, c0), c2))))
  anbi2d(wceq(cv(hs0), c4), wbr(cv(s0), cfsupp, cfv(c0g, c6)), wceq(cv(hs0), co(cv(s0), cfv(clinc, c0), c2)), wceq(c4, co(cv(s0), cfv(clinc, c0), c2)))
  eqeq1(cv(hs0), c4, co(cv(s0), cfv(clinc, c0), c2))
  diff.hs0.c(c0)

  3ad2ant3(c0 ‚àà LMod, (c1 ‚àà c2 ‚àß c1 ‚äÜ c3), (c4 ‚àà(c5[‚Ü¶]c1)‚àß c4[finSupp]c6), c4 ‚àà((Base `(Scalar ` c0))[‚Ü¶]c1))

  syl3anc(((c0 ‚àà LMod ‚àß(c1 ‚àà c2 ‚àß c1 ‚äÜ c3)‚àß(c4 ‚àà(c5[‚Ü¶]c1)‚àß c4[finSupp]c6))‚àß hs0 ‚àà c1), ((c4 ` hs0)[(√ó ` c0)]hs0)‚àà c3, c0 ‚àà LMod, (c4 ` hs0)‚àà c5, hs0 ‚àà c3)

  adantl(c1 ‚àà c2, c1 ‚äÜ c3, (hs0 ‚àà c1 ‚Üí hs0 ‚àà c3))

blocks.name: linccl
blocks.content: A linear combination of vectors is a vector. (Contributed by AV, 31-Mar-2019.)
blocks.origin:
thm linccl(class c0, class c1, class c2, class c3, class c4) {
  |- wi(wa(wcel(c0, clmod), w3a(wcel(c1, cfn), wss(c1, c2), wcel(c3, co(c4, cmap, c1)))), wcel(co(c3, cfv(clinc, c0), c1), c2))
  -| wceq(c2, cfv(cbs, c0))
  -| wceq(c4, cfv(cbs, cfv(csca, c0)))
} = {
  eqeltrd(co(c3, cfv(clinc, c0), c1), c2, co(c0, cgsu, cmpt(hs0, c1, co(cfv(c3, cv(hs0)), cfv(cvsca, c0), cv(hs0)))), wa(wcel(c0, clmod), w3a(wcel(c1, cfn), wss(c1, c2), wcel(c3, co(c4, cmap, c1)))))

blocks.name: lincval1
blocks.content: The linear combination over a singleton mapping to 0. (Contributed by AV, 12-Apr-2019.)
blocks.origin:
thm lincval1(class c0, class c1, class c2, class c3, class c4, class c5) {
  |- wi(wa(wcel(c0, clmod), wcel(c1, c2)), wceq(co(c3, cfv(clinc, c0), csn(c1)), cfv(c0g, c0)))
  -| wceq(c2, cfv(cbs, c0))
  -| wceq(c4, cfv(csca, c0))
  -| wceq(c5, cfv(cbs, c4))
  -| wceq(c3, csn(cop(c1, cfv(c0g, c4))))
} = {
  eqtrd(co(c3, cfv(clinc, c0), csn(c1)), cfv(c0g, c0), co(cfv(c0g, c4), cfv(cvsca, c0), c1), wa(wcel(c0, clmod), wcel(c1, c2)))
  mpd3an3(wcel(c0, clmod), wcel(c1, c2), wceq(co(c3, cfv(clinc, c0), csn(c1)), co(cfv(c0g, c4), cfv(cvsca, c0), c1)), wcel(cfv(c0g, c4), c5))
  adantr(wcel(c0, clmod), wcel(c1, c2), wcel(cfv(c0g, c4), c5))
  lmod0cl(c0, cfv(c0g, c4), c5, c4)
  lincvalsn(c0, c1, c2, cfv(c0g, c4), c5, c3, cfv(cvsca, c0), c4)
  lmod0vs(c0, c1, c2, cfv(c0g, c4), cfv(cvsca, c0), cfv(c0g, c0), c4)
  eqid(cfv(cvsca, c0))
  eqid(cfv(c0g, c4))
  eqid(cfv(c0g, c0))
}
blocks.pretty:
thm lincval1(class c0, class c1, class c2, class c3, class c4, class c5) {
  ‚ä¢ ((c0 ‚àà LMod ‚àß c1 ‚àà c2)‚Üí(c3[(linC ` c0)]{ c1 })=(0 ` c0))
  ‚ä£ c2 =(Base ` c0)
  ‚ä£ c4 =(Scalar ` c0)
  ‚ä£ c5 =(Base ` c4)
  ‚ä£ c3 = { < c1,(0 ` c4)> }
} = {
  eqtrd((c3[(linC ` c0)]{ c1 }), (0 ` c0), ((0 ` c4)[(√ó ` c0)]c1), (c0 ‚àà LMod ‚àß c1 ‚àà c2))
  mpd3an3(c0 ‚àà LMod, c1 ‚àà c2, (c3[(linC ` c0)]{ c1 })=((0 ` c4)[(√ó ` c0)]c1), (0 ` c4)‚àà c5)
  adantr(c0 ‚àà LMod, c1 ‚àà c2, (0 ` c4)‚àà c5)
  lmod0cl(c0, (0 ` c4), c5, c4)
  lincvalsn(c0, c1, c2, (0 ` c4), c5, c3, (√ó ` c0), c4)
  lmod0vs(c0, c1, c2, (0 ` c4), (√ó ` c0), (0 ` c0), c4)
  eqid((√ó ` c0))
  eqid((0 ` c4))
  eqid((0 ` c0))
}

  syl(wa(wcel(c0, clmod), wcel(c1, c2)), wf(c3, csn(c1), c4), wcel(c3, co(c4, cmap, csn(c1))))
  syl3anc(wa(wcel(c0, clmod), wcel(c1, c2)), wcel(c3, co(c4, cmap, csn(c1))), wcel(c1, c2), wcel(cfv(c0g, c5), c4), wcel(c4, universe))

  adantr(wcel(c0, clmod), wcel(c1, c2), wcel(cfv(c0g, c5), c4))

} = {
  3eqtrd(co(c3, cfv(clinc, c0), c1), c4, co(c0, cgsu, cmpt(hs0, c1, co(cfv(c3, cv(hs0)), cfv(cvsca, c0), cv(hs0)))), co(c0, cgsu, cmpt(hs0, c1, c4)), wa(wcel(c0, clmod), wcel(c1, cpw(c2))))

blocks.name: lcoc0
blocks.content: Properties of a linear combination where all scalars are 0. (Contributed by AV, 12-Apr-2019.) (Revised by AV, 28-Jul-2019.)

thm lcoc0(setvar s0, class c0, class c1, class c2, class c3, class c4, class c5, class c6, class c7) {

  -| wceq(c2, cfv(cbs, c0))

  ralrimivw(hs0, c1, wa(wcel(c0, clmod), wcel(c1, cpw(c2))), wn(wne(c5, c5)))
  a1i(wa(wcel(c0, clmod), wcel(c1, cpw(c2))), wn(wne(c5, c5)))

  mpbird(wa(wcel(c0, clmod), wcel(c1, cpw(c2))), wcel(c3, co(c4, cmap, c1)), wf(c3, c1, c4))
  fmptd(s0, c3, c1, c4, c5, wa(wcel(c0, clmod), wcel(c1, cpw(c2))))

blocks.name: lincsum
blocks.content: The sum of two linear combinations is a linear combination, see also the proof in [Lang] p. 129. (Contributed by AV, 4-Apr-2019.) (Revised by AV, 28-Jul-2019.)

blocks.name: lincscm
blocks.content: A linear combinations multiplied with a scalar is a linear combination, see also the proof in [Lang] p. 129. (Contributed by AV, 9-Apr-2019.) (Revised by AV, 28-Jul-2019.)
blocks.origin:
thm lincscm(setvar s0, class c0, class c1, class c2, class c3, class c4, class c5, class c6, class c7, class c8) {
  |- wi(w3a(wa(wcel(c0, clmod), wcel(c1, cpw(cfv(cbs, c0)))), wa(wcel(c2, co(c3, cmap, c1)), wcel(c4, c3)), wbr(c2, cfsupp, cfv(c0g, cfv(csca, c0)))), wceq(co(c4, c5, c6), co(c7, cfv(clinc, c0), c1)))

  -| wceq(c8, cfv(cmulr, cfv(csca, c0)))
  -| wceq(c6, co(c2, cfv(clinc, c0), c1))
  -| wceq(c3, cfv(cbs, cfv(csca, c0)))
  -| wceq(c7, cmpt(s0, c1, co(c4, c8, cfv(c2, cv(s0)))))
  -| diffsc(s0, c0)
  -| diffsc(s0, c1)
  -| diffsc(s0, c2)
  -| diffsc(s0, c3)
  -| diffsc(s0, c4)
  -| diffsc(s0, c8)
} = {
  3eqtr4rd(co(c4, c5, c6), co(c7, cfv(clinc, c0), c1), co(c0, cgsu, cmpt(hs0, c1, co(c4, c5, co(cfv(c2, cv(hs0)), cfv(cvsca, c0), cv(hs0))))), co(c4, c5, co(c0, cgsu, cmpt(hs0, c1, co(cfv(c2, cv(hs0)), cfv(cvsca, c0), cv(hs0))))), w3a(wa(wcel(c0, clmod), wcel(c1, cpw(cfv(cbs, c0)))), wa(wcel(c2, co(c3, cmap, c1)), wcel(c4, c3)), wbr(c2, cfsupp, cfv(c0g, cfv(csca, c0)))))
  gsumvsmul(hs0, c0, c1, c4, c5, co(cfv(c2, cv(hs0)), cfv(cvsca, c0), cv(hs0)), cfv(cbs, c0), cfv(csca, c0), c3, cfv(c0g, c0), cfv(cplusg, c0), cpw(cfv(cbs, c0)), w3a(wa(wcel(c0, clmod), wcel(c1, cpw(cfv(cbs, c0)))), wa(wcel(c2, co(c3, cmap, c1)), wcel(c4, c3)), wbr(c2, cfsupp, cfv(c0g, cfv(csca, c0)))))

  eqtrd(co(c7, cfv(clinc, c0), c1), co(c0, cgsu, cmpt(hs0, c1, co(c4, c5, co(cfv(c2, cv(hs0)), cfv(cvsca, c0), cv(hs0))))), co(c0, cgsu, cmpt(hs0, c1, co(cfv(c7, cv(hs0)), cfv(cvsca, c0), cv(hs0)))), w3a(wa(wcel(c0, clmod), wcel(c1, cpw(cfv(cbs, c0)))), wa(wcel(c2, co(c3, cmap, c1)), wcel(c4, c3)), wbr(c2, cfsupp, cfv(c0g, cfv(csca, c0)))))

blocks.name: lincsumcl
blocks.content: The sum of two linear combinations is a linear combination, see also the proof in [Lang] p. 129. (Contributed by AV, 4-Apr-2019.) (Proof shortened by AV, 28-Jul-2019.)
blocks.origin:
thm lincsumcl(class c0, class c1, class c2, class c3, class c4) {
  |- wi(wa(wa(wcel(c0, clmod), wcel(c1, cpw(cfv(cbs, c0)))), wa(wcel(c2, co(c0, clinco, c1)), wcel(c3, co(c0, clinco, c1)))), wcel(co(c2, c4, c3), co(c0, clinco, c1)))
  -| wceq(c4, cfv(cplusg, c0))
} = {

blocks.name: lincscmcl
blocks.content: The multiplication of a linear combination with a scalar is a linear combination, see also the proof in [Lang] p. 129. (Contributed by AV, 11-Apr-2019.) (Proof shortened by AV, 28-Jul-2019.)

blocks.name: lincsumscmcl
blocks.content: The sum of a linear combination and a multiplication of a linear combination with a scalar is a linear combination. (Contributed by AV, 11-Apr-2019.)

blocks.name: lincolss
blocks.content: According to the statement in [Lang] p. 129, the set ` ( LSubSp `` M ) ` of all linear combinations of a set of vectors V is a submodule (_generated_ by V) of the module M. The elements of V are called _generators_ of ` ( LSubSp `` M ) ` . (Contributed by AV, 12-Apr-2019.)

blocks.name: ellcoellss
blocks.content: Every linear combination of a subset of a linear subspace is also contained in the linear subspace. (Contributed by AV, 20-Apr-2019.) (Proof shortened by AV, 30-Jul-2019.)

blocks.name: lcoss
blocks.content: A set of vectors of a module is a subset of the set of all linear combinations of the set. (Contributed by AV, 18-Apr-2019.) (Proof shortened by AV, 30-Jul-2019.)
blocks.origin:

thm lspsslco(class c0, class c1, class c2) {
  |- wi(wa(wcel(c0, clmod), wcel(c1, cpw(c2))), wss(cfv(cfv(clspn, c0), c1), co(c0, clinco, c1)))
  -| wceq(c2, cfv(cbs, c0))
} = {
  syl3anc(wa(wcel(c0, clmod), wcel(c1, cpw(c2))), wss(cfv(cfv(clspn, c0), c1), co(c0, clinco, c1)), wcel(c0, clmod), wcel(co(c0, clinco, c1), cfv(clss, c0)), wss(c1, co(c0, clinco, c1)))
  simpl(wcel(c0, clmod), wcel(c1, cpw(c2)))
  sylan2b(wcel(c0, clmod), wcel(c1, cpw(c2)), wcel(co(c0, clinco, c1), cfv(clss, c0)), wcel(c1, cpw(cfv(cbs, c0))))
  lincolss(c0, c1)
  sylan2b(wcel(c0, clmod), wcel(c1, cpw(c2)), wss(c1, co(c0, clinco, c1)), wcel(c1, cpw(cfv(cbs, c0))))
  eleq2i(c1, cpw(c2), cpw(cfv(cbs, c0)))
  pweqi(c2, cfv(cbs, c0))
  lcoss(c0, c1)
  lspssp(c0, co(c0, clinco, c1), cfv(clss, c0), c1, cfv(clspn, c0))
  eqid(cfv(clss, c0))
  eqid(cfv(clspn, c0))
}

  rspcv(hs2, hs0, (c0[LinCo]c1), hs2 ‚àà hs1, hs0 ‚àà hs1)
  elequ1(hs2, hs0, hs1)
  elintrab(hs1, hs0, (LSubSp ` c0), c1 ‚äÜ hs1)
  vex(hs0)
  syl2anc(((c0 ‚àà LMod ‚àß c1 ‚àà P(c2))‚àß hs0 ‚àà(c0[LinCo]c1)), ((LSpan ` c0)` c1)= ‚ãÇ { hs1 ‚àà(LSubSp ` c0)| c1 ‚äÜ hs1 }, c0 ‚àà LMod, c1 ‚äÜ c2)
  simpll(c0 ‚àà LMod, c1 ‚àà P(c2), hs0 ‚àà(c0[LinCo]c1))
  ad2antlr(c0 ‚àà LMod, c1 ‚àà P(c2), hs0 ‚àà(c0[LinCo]c1), c1 ‚äÜ c2)
  elpwi(c1, c2)
  lspval(hs1, c0, c1, c2, (LSpan ` c0), (LSubSp ` c0))
  eqid((LSubSp ` c0))
  eqid((LSpan ` c0))
  diff.hs0.c((c0[LinCo]c1))
  diff.hs0.c(((LSpan ` c0)` c1))
  diff.hs0.w((c0 ‚àà LMod ‚àß c1 ‚àà P(c2)))
  diff.hs1.w(((c0 ‚àà LMod ‚àß c1 ‚àà P(c2))‚àß hs0 ‚àà(c0[LinCo]c1)))
  diff.hs2.c(c0)
  diff.hs2.c(hs1)
  diff.hs2.c(c1)
  diff.hs2.c(hs0)
  diff.hs2.c((c0[LinCo]c1))
  diff.hs2.w(hs0 ‚àà hs1)
  diff.hs1.c(hs0)
  diff.hs1.c(c1)
  diff.hs1.c(c2)
  diff.hs1.c((LSubSp ` c0))
}

blocks.name: lspeqlco
blocks.content: Equivalence of a _span_ of a set of vectors of a left module defined as the intersection of all linear subspaces which each contain every vector in that set (see ~ df-lsp ) and as the set of all linear combinations of the vectors of the set with finite support. (Contributed by AV, 20-Apr-2019.)
